**Associate Justices of the Supreme Court of the United States** are the
members of the [Supreme Court of the United
States](/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States "Supreme Court of the United
States") other than the [Chief Justice of the United
States](/wiki/Chief_Justice_of_the_United_States "Chief Justice of the United
States"). The number of associate justices is determined by the [United States
Congress](/wiki/United_States_Congress "United States Congress") and is
currently set at eight by the [Judiciary Act of
1869](/wiki/Judiciary_Act_of_1869 "Judiciary Act of 1869").

Like the chief justice, associate justices are nominated by the [President of
the United States](/wiki/President_of_the_United_States "President of the
United States") and are confirmed by the [United States
Senate](/wiki/United_States_Senate "United States Senate") by majority vote.
This is provided for in [Article
II](/wiki/Article_Two_of_the_United_States_Constitution "Article Two of the
United States Constitution") of the
[Constitution](/wiki/United_States_Constitution "United States Constitution"),
which states that the president "shall nominate, and by and with the [Advice
and Consent](/wiki/Advice_and_consent "Advice and consent") of the Senate,
shall appoint... Judges of the supreme Court." Although the Constitution
refers to them as "Judges of the Supreme Court", the title actually used is
"Associate Justice", introduced in the [Judiciary Act of
1789](/wiki/Judiciary_Act_of_1789 "Judiciary Act of 1789").[1] Associate
justices were traditionally styled "Mr. Justice" in court opinions, but the
title was shortened to "Justice" in 1980, a year before [Sandra Day
O'Connor](/wiki/Sandra_Day_O%27Connor "Sandra Day O'Connor") became the first
female justice.[2]

[Article III](/wiki/Article_Three_of_the_United_States_Constitution "Article
Three of the United States Constitution") of the Constitution specifies that
associate justices, and all other [United States federal
judges](/wiki/United_States_federal_judge "United States federal judge")
"shall hold their Offices during good Behavior". This language means that the
appointments are effectively [for life](/wiki/Life_tenure "Life tenure"), and
that, once
[confirmed](/wiki/Appointment_and_confirmation_to_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States#Confirmation
"Appointment and confirmation to the Supreme Court of the United States"), a
justice's tenure of office ends only when they [die](/wiki/Death "Death"),
[retire](/wiki/Retirement "Retirement"), resign, or are removed from office
through the [impeachment process](/wiki/Impeachment_in_the_United_States
"Impeachment in the United States").

Each Supreme Court justice has a single vote in deciding the cases argued
before it; the chief justice's vote counts no more than that of any other
justice. However, in drafting opinions, the chief justice enjoys additional
influence in case disposition if in the majority through his power to assign
who writes the opinion. Otherwise, the senior justice in the majority assigns
the writing of a decision. Furthermore, the chief justice leads the discussion
of the case among the justices. The chief justice has certain administrative
responsibilities that the other justices do not and is paid slightly more
($255,500 per year, as opposed to $244,400 per year for each associate
justice[3]).

Associate justices have seniority by order of appointment, although the chief
justice is always considered to be the most senior. If two justices are
appointed on the same day, the older is designated the senior justice of the
two. Currently, the senior associate justice is [Anthony
Kennedy](/wiki/Anthony_Kennedy "Anthony Kennedy"). By tradition, when the
justices are in conference deliberating the outcome of cases before the Court,
the justices state their views in order of seniority. The senior associate
justice is also tasked with carrying out the chief justices's duties when he
is unable to, or if that office is vacant.[4]

## Retired associate
justices[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Associate_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Retired associate justices")]

An associate justice who leaves the Court after attaining the age and meeting
the service requirements prescribed by federal statute ([28
U.S.C.](/wiki/Title_28_of_the_United_States_Code "Title 28 of the United
States Code") [§ 371](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/28/371)) may
retire in [senior status](/wiki/Senior_status "Senior status") rather than
resign. After retirement, they keep their title, and by custom may also keep a
set of chambers in the Supreme Court building, and employ law clerks. The
names of retired associate justices continue to appear alongside those of the
active justices in the bound volumes of Supreme Court decisions. Federal
statute ([28 U.S.C.](/wiki/Title_28_of_the_United_States_Code "Title 28 of the
United States Code") [§ 294](https://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/text/28/294))
provides that retired Supreme Court justices may serve—if designated and
assigned by the chief justice—on panels of the U.S. courts of appeals, or on
the U.S. district courts. Retired justices are not, however, authorized to
take part in the consideration or decision of any cases before the Supreme
Court (unlike other retired federal judges who may be permitted do so in their
former courts); neither are they known or designated as a "senior judge".
When, after his retirement, [William O. Douglas](/wiki/William_O._Douglas
"William O. Douglas") attempted to take a more active role than was customary,
maintaining that it was his prerogative to do so because of his senior status,
he was rebuffed by Chief Justice [Warren Burger](/wiki/Warren_Burger "Warren
Burger") and admonished by the whole Court.[5]

Currently, there are three living retired associate justices: [Sandra Day
O'Connor](/wiki/Sandra_Day_O%27Connor "Sandra Day O'Connor"), retired January
31, 2006; [David Souter](/wiki/David_Souter "David Souter"), retired June 29,
2009; and [John Paul Stevens](/wiki/John_Paul_Stevens "John Paul Stevens"),
retired June 29, 2010. Both O'Connor and Souter occasionally serve on panels
of the Courts of Appeals of various circuits. Stevens has not performed any
judicial duties.

Notes[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Associate_Justice_of_the_Supreme_Court_of_the_United_States&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Notes")]

  1. **Jump up ^** Listed here (unless otherwise noted) is the position—either with a U.S. state or the federal government, or with a private corporation—held by the individual immediately prior to becoming an Associate Justice of the Supreme Court.
  2. **Jump up ^** Later served as chief justice, June 30, 1795 – December 28, 1795.
  3. ^ Jump up to: _**a**_ _**b**_ _**c**_ _**d**_ _**e**_ _**f**_ _**g**_ Recess appointment.
  4. **Jump up ^** Received recess appointment on August 5, 1791, but was not sworn in until August 6, 1792.
  5. **Jump up ^** Was impeached, but not convicted (remained in office).
  6. **Jump up ^** Served as chief justice, December 19, 1910 – May 19, 1921.
  7. **Jump up ^** Later served as chief justice, February 13, 1930 – June 30, 1941.
  8. **Jump up ^** Served as chief justice, July 3, 1941 – April 22, 1946.
  9. **Jump up ^** Served as chief justice, September 26, 1986 – September 3, 2005.
